Fig. 1 Mass based intrinsic rate constants (k) at 380 °C after ageing vs Zn/Al molar ratio. Each catalyst is promoted with 2.2 wt% K. The space velocity and feed gas composition were SV = 25,900 ± 2000 Nl/kg/h and 10.1% CO, 36.8% H2O, 6.3% CO2, 44.7% H2 and 2.1% Ar. Blue dots are data points; the orange dashed line is to guide the eye. (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.) Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Mass based intrinsic rate constants after ageing of alkali promoted catalysts (0.58 mmol/g) at a Zn/Al molar ratio of 0.62 versus promoter ionic radius. Test conditions as in Fig. 1. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Surface area-based intrinsic rate constants after ageing of alkali promoted catalysts (0.58 mmol/g) and an un-promoted sample (orange columns, left axis) and BET area of spent catalysts (blue line, right axis). Test conditions as in Fig. 1. (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.) Fig. 3 Fig. 4 Intrinsic rate constants versus [K] of aged catalysts. Orange curve (left scale): mass-based rate constants; Blue curve (right scale): surface-area based rate constants. Conditions as in Fig. 1. (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.) Fig. 4 Fig. 5 XRD data for the fresh (A) and aged (B) catalyst series with the K-concentration varied. Rietveld deconvolution of the ZnO and ZnAl2O4 contributions to the observed XRD data are shown for the K-free 0–0.62–0.00 fresh (C) and aged (D) samples respectively. Characteristic non-overlapped peaks are marked with stars and rhombs for the ZnAl2O4 and ZnO phases, respectively. Black arrows in B) mark the peaks appearing as a result of a new K-rich phase. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Evolution of ZnAl2O4 (blue, left axis) and ZnO (orange, right axis) particle sizes through the K-series in aged samples, showing the inhibiting effect of K on ZnAl2O4 crystal growth, levelling out at [K] above 2.1 wt%. Insertion: The K-rich phase begins to appear at [K] = 4 wt%. This coincides with increasing ZnO crystal growth. (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.) Fig. 6 Fig. 7 A: ZnAl2O4 spinel size (blue curve, left axis) and BET area (orange curve, right axis) versus the K surface concentration. B: Intrinsic rate constants on mass-basis (blue curve, left axis) and on surface area-basis (orange curve, right axis) versus K surface concentration. (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.) Fig. 7 Fig. 8 Two structural representations of the spinel (111) surface emphasizing the kagome layer. The green spheres represent K+ ions filling the aluminum vacancies. Light blue spheres are Al3+ ions, gray spheres are Zn2+ ions and the red spheres represent O2- ions. (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.) Fig. 8 Fig. 9 FTIR-CO spectra during CO desorption for the un-promoted sample 0–0.62–0.00 (a) and the K-promoted sample K-0.62–2.33 (b). The dark green lines represent high CO coverages, while the light green and yellow to red lines represent decreasing CO coverages. A direct comparison between spectra of the un-promoted (continuous line) and the K-promoted (dashed line) samples during IR-CO desorption at high and low CO partial pressures (c). Fig. 9 Fig. 10 Relative activities after ageing at various temperatures. Each data point is obtained as the STY(t)/STY(500) at 400 °C, where t is the time in hours. In between data points, the temperature was adjusted to 400, 570 or 620 °C, respectively. STY(500) is 34.7 ± 1.9 mol/kg/h for all three catalysts. Fig. 10 Fig. 11 Activity (blue dots) as STY during exposure to syngas with and without H2S. The yellow line is prediction by the model for deactivation in the sulfur-containing synthesis gas described in the text. Temperature and H2S concentration are shown as black lines. (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.) Fig. 11 Table 1 Characterization and activity of spent catalysts. Lundegaard Pablo Beato Raul Montesano Jens Sehested Haldor Topsoe A/S, Haldor Topsøes Allé 1, DK-2800 Kongens Lyngby, Denmark Haldor Topsoe A/S Haldor Topsøes Allé 1 Kongens Lyngby DK-2800 Denmark N. C. Schjødt, Cand. Polyt. S. L. Jørgensen, L. F. Lundegaard, P. Beato, R. Montesano and J. Sehested Haldor Topsoe A/S, Haldor Topsøes Allé 1, DK-2800 Kgs. Lyngby, Denmark ⁎ Corresponding author. A new kind of high-temperature water gas shift catalyst based on K-promoted ZnO/ZnAl2O4, introduced by Haldor Topsøe as SK-501 Flex™, has begun to replace the well-known Fe/Cr oxide catalysts in the industry. In this research article, we focus on optimization of the catalyst system, especially on promotion with alkali metals and on structural characterization using X-ray diffraction. The promotional effect of the alkali metals increases in the order Li < < Na < < Cs < Rb < K. With K, a 20-fold increase of the mass-based intrinsic rate constant compared to an un-promoted sample is observed. The optimum in the K-content, 2.1 wt%, corresponds to a surface concentration of 0.0057 mmol/m2 or 0.0059 mmol/m2 if K only decorates the ZnAl2O4 spinel surface. This coverage coincides with the surface concentration of Al vacancies on the dominating spinel (111) facet, the so-called kagome layer, with a coverage of 0.00586 mmol/m2. Potassium decoration of the spinel surface is corroborated by FTIR studies of promoted and un-promoted samples in a CO atmosphere. The promotion by potassium is both structural, inhibiting growth of the spinel crystals as evidenced by XRD and BET surface area measurements, but also electronic since the activity per surface area strongly increases on K-promotion. Finally, our studies include long term tests of thermal stability and tolerance towards H2S. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Water gas shift Catalyst Zinc oxide Zinc spinel Alkali promoter Potassium promoter 1 Introduction For several decades, the water gas shift reaction (WGS) has been an integrated part of hydrogen production such as in ammonia plants and in refineries, and several reviews on WGS catalysts have been published [1–4]. The reaction, being exothermic and equilibrium limited, is often conducted in two stages in adiabatic reactors using a high-temperature shift (HTS) reactor and a low-temperature shift (LTS) reactor, each with appropriate catalysts. The discovery by BASF of the catalytic activity of iron oxide for the WGS reaction more than a century ago [5] has been a corner stone in industrial chemistry. Modern formulations are based on Fe/Cr oxide with various promoters such as Cu and Ca. These catalysts have served the industry well but are inherently vulnerable to over-reduction since the active phase, Fe3O4, can be reduced to iron carbides or elemental iron causing severe loss of mechanical strength and selectivity, which happens if the reduction potential of the gas is too high. This limitation of the iron-based catalysts implies that the HTS reaction needs to be conducted in a surplus of steam, which increases the total net energy consumption of the plant. Also, the chromium is a potential hazard for human health and the environment not least during unload where oxidation by air may lead to formation of Cr(VI) species in the spent catalyst charge. However, despite many attempts [6,7], it has proved very difficult to find other catalyst systems with sufficient performance to substitute the Fe/Cr based HTS catalysts. We report here a thorough study of a catalyst system first mentioned in the patent literature [8], which is now beginning to get attention from academia as well [9,10]. It is based on ZnO/ZnAl2O4 promoted by alkali metals, and we find this catalyst system to have outstanding activity, selectivity, resistance towards common poisons and thermal stability. This catalyst system is studied here by a series of techniques including X-ray diffraction (XRD) and FTIR spectroscopy to elucidate the role of the crucial alkali promoter. The potassium promoted ZnO/ZnAl2O4 catalyst is an environmentally friendly and industrially proven next generation high temperature shift catalyst. The catalyst can be further promoted by Cu in low concentrations (1–5 wt%). 2 Experimental 2.1 Sample preparation and nomenclature Three series of catalysts were prepared: (1) Variation of Zn/Al molar ratio in the range 0.43–1.00 with 2.2 ± 0.2 wt% K. (2) Promotion with different alkali metals at 0.58 ± 0.06 mmol/g. (3) Variation of K-content from 0 to 8.75 wt%. The second and third series were prepared from the same batch with a Zn/Al molar ratio of 0.62. All ZnO/ZnAl2O4 catalysts were prepared by co-precipitation, combining aqueous solutions of KAlO2/KOH, K2CO3 and Zn(NO3)2 by a published procedure [8]. The precipitate was washed thoroughly prior to drying and pre-calcination at 225 °C. The pre-calcined samples were crushed and sieved to the fraction 0.15–0.30 mm and impregnated with the appropriate amount of M2CO3 solution (M = alkali metal; for M = Li, LiHCO2 was used) by the incipient wetness technique. An un-promoted sample was prepared similarly by impregnation with pure water. All samples were dried at 100 °C, mixed with 4 wt% graphite, shaped as 6 × 6 mm cylindrical tablets with density 1.82 ± 0.12 g/cm3, calcined at 450 °C for four hours and routinely analyzed for elemental composition (ICP-OES), surface area (N2 adsorption/desorption by the BET method) as well as phase identification and crystal size (powder XRD). The catalysts are designated P-Z-X where P is the promoter, Z is the Zn/Al molar ratio and X is the content of alkali promoter in wt% in the catalyst. Table SI-1 lists the fresh samples and some physical and chemical characterizations. 2.2 Catalyst testing All catalysts were tested in an electrically heated tubular reactor with an inner diameter of 6.7 mm. The catalyst was loaded as a single pellet string where each catalyst tablet was separated from its neighbors by a 5 mm sphere of dead-burned α-alumina, confirmed to be inactive in a separate test. The total bed height was kept constant at 105 mm, using a catalyst load of 3.9 ± 0.3 g. Catalyst activity was measured under quasi-isothermal conditions at a total pressure of 2.50 MPa at a flow rate of 101 Nl/h (GHSV = 25,900 ± 2000 Nl/kg/h) using a feed gas of the composition 10.1% CO, 36.8% H2O, 6.3% CO2, 44.7% H2 and 2.1% Ar as internal standard. The exit gas was cooled, removing water by condensation under pressure, and the dry exit gas was analyzed by gas chromatography using an Agilent 6890 N gas chromatograph calibrated towards a similar gas of known composition. Carbon mass balances were accurate within ± 1%. Each catalyst was tested in a sequence of temperatures 330–380–430–480–380 °C. At each temperature the conditions were maintained for a period of 5–10 h until constant activity was observed by at least three consecutive GC analysis which were identical within experimental error. Both inlet and exit gases were analyzed several times during each run. For data treatment, an average of the stable GC analysis has been used. At each condition the space-time yield (STY) was calculated as mol CO converted per kg catalyst per hour, using the specific flow rates, catalyst mass and CO-conversion. In the following, we use only the activity data obtained in the final measurement at 380 °C and refer to this as “after ageing” or “spent catalyst”. 2.3 X-ray diffraction For the XRD analysis the catalyst samples were investigated with a PanAlytical X′Pert Pro instrument in Bragg-Brentano Geometry in reflectance mode using a Cu Kα radiation source (λ = 1.541 Å) at ambient conditions. The scan range was 5–70° with a step size of 0.017°. The Rietveld analysis was performed using the Topas software. Crystallite sizes of ZnAl2O4 and ZnO were constrained to have minimum sizes of 5 nm and 4 nm respectively, to avoid correlation with parameters describing the scattering background. The result of the Rietveld analysis is presented in Tables SI-1 (fresh catalysts) and Table 1 (spent catalysts). 2.4 Spectroscopy Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectra of adsorbed CO were collected on a Bruker FTIR spectrometer (Vertex 70) equipped with a MCT cryo-detector. Self-supporting wafers (20 mg) of samples were loaded in a low-temperature adsorption quartz cell connected to a vacuum line. Samples were subsequently calcined in situ at 450 °C for 8 h in synthetic air, before vacuum was applied while cooling to liquid N2 temperature. At a pressure and temperature of 3.00 × 10−3 mbar and − 180 °C, samples were exposed to CO pulses until no further changes were observed in the spectra. CO desorption was performed in the same way, step-wise at − 180 °C. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Calculation of intrinsic rate constants In the pellet-string tests the flow area between the inner reactor wall and the outer diameter of the catalyst tablets was small, hence the external transport limitations were minimal. Nevertheless, external heat transfer coefficients were calculated according to [11], assuming that the tablets were placed coaxially to the reactor tube. Regarding the intraparticle transport restrictions, these were accounted for by means of effective pore diffusivities. Average pore volumes and sizes were obtained by N2 porosimetry for a spent sample having 2.3 wt% K and a Zn/Al molar ratio of 0.57. Subsequently, the pore radii of the catalysts in Table 1 were calculated from the BET surface areas as r = 2 V g / S g . It was assumed that the skeletal density was the same for all samples. The intrinsic reaction rate was calculated as r = k ∙ p CO 1.04 ∙ p CO 2 − 0.25 ∙ p H 2 O 0.16 1 − β , which is the equation used by Antoniak-Jurak, et al. [9]. A similar dependency of the water-gas shift rate on the gas composition was found by Rethwisch and Dumesic [12] over unpromoted bulk ZnO. The reactor was simulated by a one-dimensional heterogeneous model; the intrinsic rate constants, k , were adjusted iteratively until the measured and the calculated CO conversions agreed. In the following, we will use either the observed reaction rates in the form of space-time yield (STY) or the intrinsic rate constants (k) calculated as described above, to address the catalyst activity. 3.2 Variation of Zn/Al molar ratio in the range 0.43–1.00 with 2.2 ± 0.2 wt% K In the first series of catalysts, the Zn/Al molar ratio was varied around the spinel stoichiometry (ZnAl = 0.5). Fig. 1 shows the final activity at 380 °C after ageing, expressed as mass-based intrinsic rate constants, for six catalysts with Zn/Al molar ratio in the range 0.43–1.00 each promoted with 2.2 ± 0.2 wt% K. A broad maximum is observed around ZnAl = 0.6. An outlier appears at ZnAl = 0.58 with an intrinsic rate constant of 2.42 Ndm3 g−1 h−1 atm−0.95, which is approximately 10% lower than expected if it should obey to the line in Fig. 1. We note that the fresh sample of this catalyst has a BET surface area of only 140 m2/g, which is also lower than expected when compared to the BET area of the other fresh samples in this series (see Table SI-1). We suspect that the calcination temperature was accidentally set higher than intended for this catalyst. Zn/Al oxides have previously been studied as catalysts for the reverse water gas shift (RWGS) reaction by Park et al. [13]. In that study, the catalysts were optimized according to the Zn/Al molar ratio, but alkali promotion was not investigated. Park et al. concluded that although ZnO is more active than ZnAl2O4, the latter is far more stable at the high temperatures required to get substantial equilibrium conversion in the RWGS reaction. The lack of stability of ZnO was ascribed to its (partial) reduction to metallic Zn at the reaction conditions. The catalysts in the present study were found to be stable in synthesis gas up to 570 °C, whereas at 620 °C the activity declined rapidly (see Section 3.6). This observation is in good agreement with the results reported by Park et al., where it was shown that catalysts with a Zn:Al ratio of 4:1 and 1:1 deactivated quite rapidly at 600 °C whereas a catalyst with the stoichiometric spinel ratio of 1:2 was stable. This agrees with our data in Fig. 1, showing a decline in activity at high Zn/Al molar ratios. The potassium promoter however, affects ZnO sites and ZnAl2O4 sites differently, as will be discussed in Section 3.4. 3.3 Promotion with different alkali metals at 0.58 ± 0.06 mmol/g Fig. 2 concerns the second series of catalysts, each with a Zn/Al molar ratio of 0.62 and promoted with 0.58 ± 0.06 mmol/g of alkali metal, including the un-promoted reference sample. The graph shows the activity at 380 °C measured at the end of the temperature sequence (aged catalysts) versus the promoter ionic radius in octahedral coordination [14]. Considering the similarity in the chemistry of the alkali metals, the very large difference in promoting effect among them (K > Rb > Cs >> Na >> Li) is striking and indicates a structural aspect of the promotional effect. This is discussed further in Section 3.4. The fresh catalyst samples with different promoters (including the un-promoted sample) appear very similar in XRD (see Table SI-1). The distribution of phases was 77 ± 2 wt% ZnAl2O4 with a lattice constant a = 8.100 ± 0.003 Å and an estimated crystal size of 5.0 nm, and 23 ± 2 wt% ZnO with a lattice constant c = 5.18 ± 0.01 Å and an estimated crystal size of 4.0 nm. No promoter phase could be detected. The spent catalysts were also analysed by BET and XRD, revealing very different impact of the various promoters on the sintering of the zinc spinel and zinc oxide phases. These data are collected in Table 1. It is worth noticing that the spinel fraction increases at the expense of the ZnO phase when going from fresh to spent catalysts, indicating that spinel formation between ZnO and Al2O3 takes place during operation. Apart from the structural data, Table 1 includes the activity of aged catalysts (conditions as in Fig. 1) both as observed activity in terms of STY and in terms of the mass-based and surface area-based intrinsic rate constants, calculated as described in Section 3.1. The results of Antoniak-Jurak et al. (Table 2 in [9]) show STY’s of 25.0–63.8 mol/kg/h at 370 °C measured on crushed and sieved catalyst (0.16–0.25 mm grain size) under conditions, which are otherwise not far from those used by us. To compare, we obtained STY’s on 6 × 6 mm tablets in the range 12.9–53.2 mol/kg/h (aged catalysts). A lower STY is expected when using tablets compared to using crushed catalyst due to lower effectiveness factor. The strong promotional effect of K is clear from Table 1. The measured STY is 12.9 mol·kg−1 h−1 for the un-promoted sample (0–0.62–0.00) whereas the best K-promoted sample (K-0.62-2.10) has a STY of 53.2 mol·kg−1 h−1; more than a four-fold increase. On intrinsic basis, this translates into rate constants of 0.14 and 2.93 Ndm3g−1 h−1 atm−0.95 respectively, separated by a factor of 20.9; more than an order of magnitude. Fig. 3 displays surface area-based intrinsic rate constants and BET area of the spent catalysts from the second series using different alkali promoters. The increase in surface area shows that one important role of the alkali promoter is to prevent sintering and to maintain a high surface area of the catalyst; i.e. structural promotion and apparently, the larger alkali metal ions are superior in this respect. However, if structural promotion was the only effect of the alkali metals, the activity per unit area would not increase. Hence, the alkali metals must also promote the reaction electronically. 3.4 Variation of K-content from 0 to 8.75 wt% A series of nine catalysts was prepared with variations in the potassium concentration, [K], from 0 to 8.75 wt%. Fig. 4 shows the mass-based and surface area-based intrinsic rate constants, respectively, for the entire series. An optimum at 2.1 wt% K is apparent in the mass-based rate constants, with a value of 2.93 Ndm3 g−1 h−1 atm−0.95. Inspecting the surface area-based rate constant, it increases with increasing [K] reaching a plateau around 0.03 Ndm3 m−2 h−1 atm−0.95. The samples with very high concentrations of potassium (> 4 wt%) appear to be somewhat scattered. Complications could arise from the fact that the BET area is measured at room temperature and not at 380 °C, where the activity is measured. Furthermore, the calculated rate constants become more uncertain at high (> 4 wt%) K since the new K-rich phase will influence the pore volumes and pore sizes in these catalysts. This is also reflected in the BET-area, which decreases steeply at [K] > 4 wt% (Table 1). The XRD data of the nine samples in the K-series, in the fresh and the aged state, are shown in Fig. 5. Diffraction peaks are in general broad in the fresh samples and sharper in the aged samples, which is an effect of the particle growth during aging. In the fresh samples the spinel peaks are broad and almost no variation is observed through the K-series, while a clear evolution of the spinel peak shapes is observed in the aged samples. Without addition of the K promoter, the spinel peaks are sharp showing significant particle growth, while samples with increasing amount of K-promotor display increasingly broad spinel peaks, showing less particle growth. At high K concentrations new peaks emerge in the aged samples, as indicated by the black arrows in Fig. 5. These peaks represent a K-rich third phase, but it has unfortunately not been possible to identify the phase using standard search-match techniques combined with the ICDD PDF-4+ database. Using a peak fitting technique, the area under each of the new peaks have been quantified and plotted in Fig. 6. This analysis shows that the K-rich phase starts to appear in XRD at a K content of 4 wt%. At K concentrations above this level, the ZnO particles, which for lower K concentrations do not vary significantly in size, become increasingly larger with increasing K concentrations. The evolution of spinel particle sizes through the series with variation in K loading was determined by full profile Rietveld analysis (See Fig. 5 panel C and D) and is shown in Fig. 6. Without a K promotor, there is a significant growth of spinel particles from an average size of 5–11.7 nm in the aged sample. With increasing K content there is an initial strong decrease in spinel growth during aging, but the positive effect of further K addition stops slightly above 2.1 wt% K. At higher K content the post ageing spinel sizes are independent of the K concentration and obtain sizes of approximately 6 nm. It is at these higher K concentrations that the new K phase is observed, with a linear correlation between peak areas and K content (Fig. 6). The evolution of the new K-rich phase coincides with an almost linear increase in ZnO crystal size as also shown in Fig. 6. Fig. 7 addresses the structural implications of the potassium promoter, showing (for spent catalysts) the spinel crystal size and the BET surface area (Fig. 7A) and the mass-based and surface area-based intrinsic rate constants (Fig. 7B) at increasing [K] as the surface concentration in mmol K/m2. The value of 2.1 wt% K corresponds to a surface concentration of 0.0057 mmol K/m2. There are clearly two different mechanisms at work in the two domains separated at 0.0057 mmol/m2 K, which corresponds to the surface concentration for the 2.1 wt% sample. In domain 1 the addition of K has a positive effect on the catalytic activity. An 11.5-fold increase in the surface area-based activity is observed in the 0–0.0057 mmol/m2 K range caused by the electronic promotion of K identified in Fig. 4. The more than 20-fold increase of the mass-based activity is caused partly by the electronic promotion of K and partly by the increase in active surface area, consistent with the observation that the BET surface area increases almost two-fold in the 0–0.0057 mmol/m2 K range. The increasing BET area is caused by decreased spinel sintering with increasing K content, as shown in Fig. 7A. Potassium in low concentrations will cover and stabilize the spinel surface minimizing particle growth during aging. The spinel surface obtains K saturation and maximum stability at 2.1 wt% K, and at higher concentrations a separate K-phase starts to form. Based on weight fractions and particle sizes of the spinel and ZnO phases, it is estimated (by assuming spherical particles) that less than 5% of the observed BET area is ZnO surface, while 95% is spinel surface, in the aged 2.1–8.75 wt% samples. The 2.1 wt% K evenly distributed over the observed BET surface (95 m2/g) corresponds to a total surface concentration of 0.0057 mmol/m2, while an even distribution on the spinel surface alone, results in a K surface concentration of 0.0059 mmol/m2. Spinel morphologies are often completely dominated by the (111) facet, terminated by a trihexagonal tiling arrangement of octahedrally oxygen-coordinated aluminum, also called the kagome layer. The ZnAl2O4 spinel kagome layer is characterized by containing Al vacancies in a simple hexagonal arrangement separated by 5.719 Å, corresponding to a layer concentration of 0.00586 mmol/m2. This is remarkably close to the spinel surface concentration of K for the 2.1 wt% sample calculated above, and it therefore seems reasonable to assume that K has a preference for the spinel surface until the kagome layer is saturated. It is inferred from this assumption that K is kept away from the ZnO particles in domain 1 and therefore elegantly explains why K addition has no observable effect on ZnO crystal size for [K] < 2.1 wt%. Assuming the spinel surface is terminated by a fully oxygen coordinated kagome layer, then the surface has a negative charge balance. According to Paulings electrostatic valency principle it is expected that mono valent cations such as H+ or alkali metal ions (here K+) balance the surface charge. Without K the surface is expected to be covered by terminal OH groups. Hydrogen and the alkali metals can satisfy the negative charge balance, but they do not all equally well satisfy the undercoordination of the oxygen anions associated with the Al-vacancies in the kagome layer. Here the size of the balancing cation plays an important role, explaining why the chemically similar alkali metals perform very differently (see Fig. 2). The chemical properties and size of the K+-ion results in the optimal stabilization of the spinel surface. The above observations suggest that K+ partly replaces H+ and stabilizes the spinel surface. When fully saturated, potassium is decorated on the spinel surface with one K+ associated with each Al-vacancy in the kagome layer. An example of this structure is shown in Fig. 8. As for the catalysts with [K] > 2.1 wt%, domain 2 in Fig. 7, it is possible that the newly formed K-phase wets the K-saturated spinel surface. Both the calculated rate constant and the observed activity, e.g. the STY, show a broad optimum in the range 2.10–4.14 wt% K (Table 1 and Figure SI-5). Only when [K] > 4 wt%, the mass-based activity significantly decreases, which we attribute primarily to loss of surface area, but also to the fact that in domain 2, the ZnO crystals begin to grow significantly. From a structural point of view, it is interesting to note that K acts as a sintering inhibitor towards ZnAl2O4 but as a sintering promoter towards ZnO. 3.5 FTIR studies To understand in more detail the surface structure modifications due to the presence of potassium as promoter, CO adsorption/desorption at 77 K was performed on two selected samples and monitored by FTIR spectroscopy ( Fig. 9). The two samples were an un-promoted catalyst (0–0.62–0.00) and a K-promoted catalyst (K-0.62–2.33). After exposing the calcined samples to CO at 77 K, both samples show a two-band pattern. However, the band positions and relative intensities are significantly different for samples with and without potassium. During desorption (Fig. 9a, b), the lower frequency band (at around 2152–2146 cm−1) is for both samples readily removed as the CO partial pressure is reduced, indicating a weak interaction with the surfaces. The small blue shift with respect to the gas phase frequency of the stretching vibrational mode of gas phase CO (at 2143 cm−1) and the observed weak interaction are typical for CO physisorbed on surface hydroxyl groups in oxides [16]. This band is therefore assigned to CO, interacting with the surface hydroxyl groups of the oxide phases. For this band a slight but clear difference between the K-free and the K-promoted sample can be observed. For the K-containing sample, the position of the band during desorption is almost constant at 2146 cm−1 over the whole range of CO coverages but for the K-free sample, a slight blue-shift from 2148 to 2154 cm−1 is observed as the CO coverage is reduced. This observation demonstrates that the addition of K induces changes in the distribution of surface hydroxyl groups. The modification of the surface hydroxyl groups is confirmed by comparing the spectra of the samples in the corresponding O-H stretching region (Figure SI-7). The position of the higher frequency band (at around 2199–2172 cm−1) is typical for linear adsorbed CO on coordinatively unsaturated cationic metal atoms at the surface of metal oxides [16]. For both samples the high frequency band is experiencing a large blue-shift of around Δ = 20 cm−1 as the CO coverages are lowered. Such shifts are well known from CO adsorption on metal surfaces and related to CO interaction effects at increasing coverage [17]. However, while the center-band positions range from 2175 to 2199 cm−1 for the K-free sample, the overall range is red-shifted by around 10 cm−1 for the K-containing samples, extending from 2172 to 2185 cm−1. Besides the difference in the band positions, there is also a clear difference in the relative (integral) intensities and the CO-surface bonding strength observed. To highlight the difference in band intensities with CO partial pressures, the two samples have been plotted together in one graph at high and low CO partial pressures (Fig. 9c). For the K-containing sample the observed CO stretching frequency coincides rather precisely with the reported values for CO adsorbed on surface Zn2+ sites in ZnO [18]-[19]. On the other hand, Otero et al. [20] report a band ranging from 2205 down to 2190 cm−1 for the CO stretching frequency upon increasing CO coverages on ZnAl2O4 and ascribe this band to the C-O bond frequency when interacting with coordinatively unsaturated surface Al3+ species in the spinel, similar to the observed corresponding band in transition aluminas [21]. While the center band positions are slightly higher than the ones observed in this study, this might be related to the sensitivity of the shift to the spinel stoichiometry [20]. A closer look into the IR-CO desorption spectra at low CO partial pressures (Fig. 9c, inset) reveals that in the case of the K-free sample most probably both bands, related to CO on ZnAl2O4 spinel and ZnO are present, but the much more intense bands related to the spinel is by far dominating the spectra. On the other hand, the absence of the higher frequency CO bands for the K-containing sample demonstrates that potassium effectively blocks the access of CO to the unsaturated metal sites in the spinel. One can therefore conclude from the IR-CO results that K preferentially reacts with spinel surface oxygen atoms, and thereby changes the density of surface hydroxyl groups and at the same time blocks the access of CO to the strong Al3+ adsorption sites. This is in excellent agreement with the observations from XRD, that K+ ions decorate the kagome layer of the ZnAl2O4, substituting H+ ions in surface hydroxyl groups. 3.6 Thermal stability The thermal stability of Cu- and K-promoted catalysts was tested by a series of activity measurements at 400 °C with inter-stage periods where the catalysts were exposed to higher temperatures at low GHSV, thus equilibrating the gas at the specified temperature. Two batches of catalyst with similar compositions were used (1.75 ± 0.25 wt% K, 1.7 ± 0.1 wt% Cu, ZnAl = 0.62 ± 0.05). All measurements were carried out as integral experiments in a cylindrical reactor of 19 mm inner diameter equipped with an internal multi-thermocouple with ten positions in the center of the bed. In each experiment, 40 g of catalyst were used in the shape of 6 × 6 mm cylindrical tablets. Heat was supplied to the reactor by three independent external electrical heaters. The duty of each heater was adjusted to obtain quasi-isothermal conditions throughout the catalyst bed. The feed gas composition was 9.4% CO, 6.1% CO2, 1.9% Ar, 45.0% H2, 37.6% H2O. The pressure was kept constant at 2.35 MPa. The GHSV was 20,000 Nl/kg/h during all activity measurements. The relative activity as a function of time is plotted in Fig. 10 and shows that the deactivation rate is similar at 400 and 570 °C, while it is much faster at 620 °C. During the first 500 h, all samples were pre-aged under the same conditions as in Fig. 10. 3.7 Sulfur A very common impurity in synthesis gases is sulfur in the form of H2S. If present in large amounts, so-called sour shift can be applied, using e.g. molybdenum sulfide based catalysts [15]. In most cases however, H2S is present in the ppb to ppm range in the feed gas to the HTS reactor, but H2S is a potent catalyst poison and can cause severe deactivation even in these low concentrations. We therefore exposed the catalyst to a synthesis gas containing 15 ppmV H2S. The catalyst used in this test had ZnAl = 0.67, contained 1.99 wt% K and was further promoted with 1.65 wt% Cu. The experiment was conducted at a space velocity of GHSV = 17,000 Nl/kg/h. The catalyst was initially subjected to sulfur-free synthesis gas for 167 h at 380 °C with three consecutive ageing periods at 480 °C at 12–15 h duration each. Subsequently, 15 ppmV of H2S was introduced in the feed gas. This was maintained for 464 h (TOS 167–631 h), whereupon the gas was switched back to the original sulfur-free synthesis gas for the remaining 216 h (TOS 631–847 h). Fig. 11 shows the activity as STY versus time on stream during the entire experiment. During the first period in sulfur-free gas, the activity stabilizes at around STY = 34 mol/kg/h after the first ageing cycle at 480 °C. After introduction of H2S, there is an immediate steep fall in activity from 34 to 30.8 mol/kg/h within 4 h. We hypothesize that this decline in activity reflects the loss of the activity of Cu sites in the catalyst. Then the catalyst activity declines following a much slower profile, which we attribute to the transformation of ZnO and/or ZnAl2O4 to ZnS. Within the period 171–631 h, the activity appears to strictly follow an exponential decay according to the equation STY = a ∙ e − mt + b where a + b is the initial activity, b is the residual activity at infinite time, m is the decay rate and t is time in hours. STY is the space-time yield in mol/kg/h. Best fit gave the parameters a = 21.25 mol/kg/h, b = 19.66 mol/kg/h and m = 0.003715 h−1. In the final part of the experiment, the catalyst was again exposed to sulfur-free synthesis gas. During this period the catalyst regained most of its activity, ending at 29.7 mol/kg/h or just below the 30.8 mol/kg/h in the beginning of the slower deactivation path. We hypothesize that upon addition of H2S, the Cu sites on the catalyst are immediately and irreversibly poisoned. Next, zinc is sulfided causing a further but less dramatic decrease in activity of the catalyst which, according to the model, will eventually reach an activity close to half of the initial. Analysis of the spent catalyst revealed a sulfur content of 5.08 wt%. XRD revealed 34 wt% ZnS (Wurtzite), 28 wt% ZnO, 34 wt% ZnAl2O4 and 2 wt% Cu. SEM analysis of a spent catalyst tablet showed a distinct gray-yellow rim with a width of 900–1100 µm while the interior of the tablet was plain gray. This is shown in Figure SI-6 together with EDS mapping of the two areas showing that sulfur uptake occurs from the outside towards the internal of the tablet. 4 Conclusion Alkali doped ZnO/ZnAl2O4 catalysts for the high-temperature water gas shift reaction have been studied with special attention to the alkali promoter. The alkali metal ions appear in order of increasing promotional effect as Li < < Na < < Cs < Rb < K, indicating an important structural significance of the promoter. Structure-activity correlations could be inferred from XRD of the spent catalyst samples with a Zn/Al molar ratio of 0.62, revealing two domains of K-promotion. In domain 1, from 0.0 to 2.1 wt% K, the activity increases steeply with increasing potassium content. This is valid both for the observed space-time yield (STY) and for the intrinsic rate constant calculated from the STY using a measured pore size distribution. With increasing potassium content in domain 1, the spinel crystal sizes in the aged catalysts decrease significantly. The optimal potassium content of 2.1 wt% corresponds to a surface concentration of 0.0057 mmol/m2 or 0.0059 mmol/m2 if K covers the spinel surface only. This concentration coincides with the surface concentration of Al vacancies on the dominating spinel (111) facet, the so-called kagome layer, with a coverage of 0.00586 mmol/m2. Thus, in domain 1, we conclude that K+ ions decorate the spinel surface, filling Al vacancies and substituting H+ ions on surface hydroxyl groups, which is corroborated by FTIR spectroscopy in a CO atmosphere. Furthermore, the ZnO crystal size is constant within experimental error in domain 1. The surface area-based intrinsic rate constant also increases with increasing potassium content in domain 1, which is evidence that potassium acts not only as structural promoter but also as electronic promoter. In domain 2, at 2.1–8.75 wt% K, spinel crystal size is almost constant while the BET area begins to decline along with the mass-based activity. At 4.0 wt% K and above, a new, K-rich phase begins to appear in XRD. Simultaneously, ZnO shows increasing crystal growth with increasing K-content, indicating a stronger interaction between K+ ions and ZnO than in domain 1. In domain 2, the mass-based activity slowly declines at 2.1–4.0 wt% K and then declines steeply at even higher K concentrations. Finally, we have conducted studies on Cu/K/ZnO/ZnAl2O4 catalysts, of thermal stability showing an upper limit of at least 570 °C without significant deactivation for this catalyst, along with studies on sulfur poisoning which, according to a simple exponential decay model, suggests a residual catalyst activity (as STY) of close to half of the original after constant operation at 15 ppmV H2S. coredata.dc:description: A new kind of high-temperature water gas shift catalyst based on K-promoted ZnO/ZnAl2O4, introduced by Haldor Topsøe as SK-501 Flex™, has begun to replace the well-known Fe/Cr oxide catalysts in the industry. In this research article, we focus on optimization of the catalyst system, especially on promotion with alkali metals and on structural characterization using X-ray diffraction. The promotional effect of the alkali metals increases in the order Li < < Na < < Cs < Rb < K. With K, a 20-fold increase of the mass-based intrinsic rate constant compared to an un-promoted sample is observed. The optimum in the K-content, 2.1 wt%, corresponds to a surface concentration of 0.0057 mmol/m2 or 0.0059 mmol/m2 if K only decorates the ZnAl2O4 spinel surface. This coverage coincides with the surface concentration of Al vacancies on the dominating spinel (111) facet, the so-called kagome layer, with a coverage of 0.00586 mmol/m2. Potassium decoration of the spinel surface is corroborated by FTIR studies of promoted and un-promoted samples in a CO atmosphere. The promotion by potassium is both structural, inhibiting growth of the spinel crystals as evidenced by XRD and BET surface area measurements, but also electronic since the activity per surface area strongly increases on K-promotion. Finally, our studies include long term tests of thermal stability and tolerance towards H2S.
coredata.dc:title: Alkali promoted zinc-aluminum oxide as high temperature water gas shift catalyst
